answers.answer: Hello.You have describes the tingling or the paresthesia nicely. I would think of a bilateral mild peripheral nerve problem. You have to be looking at the low back, or the lumbar spine. AT this age, the intervertebral discs tend to bulge out due to the pressure. Sometimes even a small bulge may produce significant symptoms. A preliminary neurological examination by a neurologist will be extremely helpful, as will be an imaging study (CT scan or MRI) of the lumbar spine.Further exploration can be directed towards possible vitamin deficiencies, diabetes, etc.Regards

question: I am not sure how to describe the tingling in my legs but when you were a kid, did you ever have the rock candy that when you put it into your mouth, it would fizzle and tingle.  Well, that is what my legs feel like but mostly in the calf area and around to the outer sides of the leg.  Can you tell me what this might be!I am 50 years old and a female.  Going through the change but this has been going on since before that.Thank you for your time!Melanie
title: Sensations in Legs
